# 1. Introduction

## 1. Introduction

::: {.fragment}
In *comparative judgments* (CJ) studies [@Thurstone_1927a; @Thurstone_1927b]
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: incremental
- judges assess a specific trait or attribute
- across different stimuli
- by performing pairwise comparisons
- producing a dichotomous outcome
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
e.g., when assessing writing quality, judges compare pairs of written texts (the stimuli) to determine the relative writing quality each text exhibit (the trait) 
:::

---

## 1. Introduction

::: {.fragment}
Literature have documented the effectiveness of CJ on three aspects:

::: incremental
- Reliability
- Validity
- Practical applicability
:::

:::

::: {.fragment}
But the methodology have **some issues** ...
:::

::: {.notes}
Result on **reliability:**

- CJ needs a modest number of pairwise comparisons [@Verhavert_et_al_2019; @Crompvoets_et_al_2022] 
- CJ can generate precise and consistent trait scores compared to other assessment methods [@Coertjens_et_al_2017; @Goossens_et_al_2018; @Bouwer_et_al_2023].
- CJ has equal, if not superior, time efficiency than other assessment methods when employing adaptive comparison algorithms [@Pollitt_2012b; @Verhavert_et_al_2022; @Mikhailiuk_et_al_2021].

Result on **validity:**

- CJ scores represent accurately the traits under measurement [@Whitehouse_2012; @vanDaal_et_al_2016; @Lesterhuis_2018_thesis; @Bartholomew_et_al_2018; @Bouwer_et_al_2023].

Result on **practical applicability:**

- CJ is versatile across both educational and non-educational contexts [@Kimbell_2012; @Jones_et_al_2015; @Bartholomew_et_al_2018; @Jones_et_al_2019; @Marshall_et_al_2020; @Bartholomew_et_al_2020; @Boonen_et_al_2020].
:::

# 3. What are the issues?

---

## 3. What are the issues?

::: incremental
1. Excessive reliance on Case V for the analysis of CJ data
2. Disconnect between trait measurement and hypothesis testing
:::

---

## 3.1 Case V and statistical analysis

::: {.fragment style="text-align:center;"}
![Thurstones cases and their asumptions](/images/thurstone_cases.png){#tbl-thurstone_cases width=90%}
:::

::: {.notes}
Circle the assumptions of **General form**:

- correlation (one per pair)

Circle the assumptions of **Case V**:

- Equal discriminal dispersion
- Zero correlation
:::

---

### 3.1.1 The assumption of equal dispersions between stimuli

::: {.fragment style="text-align:center;"}
![The effect of dispersion discrepancies on the distribution of the discriminal difference.](/images/dispersion.png){#fig-dispersion width=60%}
:::

::: {.notes}
- $\sigma^{2}_{A}$ remains fixed
- $\rho = 0$
:::

---

### 3.1.2 The assumption of zero correlation between stimuli

::: {.fragment style="text-align:center;"}
![The effect of stimulus correlation on the distribution of the discriminal difference.](/images/correlation.png){#fig-correlation width=60%}
:::

::: {.notes}
- $\sigma^{2}_{A}$ and $\sigma^{2}_{B}$ remain fixed
:::

---

### But this is not how things happen

::: {.fragment}
In experimental practice, the experiment occurs in reverse:

::: incremental
1. Researchers observe the comparison outcome
2. Researchers use the BTL model to produce estimates of [@Thurstone_1927a, pp. 373]: 

::: incremental
::: {style="font-size:80%;"}
- the discriminal difference between the stimuli 
- their discriminal processes
:::
:::

:::

:::

::: {.fragment}
Therefore, the outcome's ability to reflect the "true" differences between stimuli **_largely depends on the validity of the model's assumptions_** [@Kohler_et_al_2019, pp. 150].
:::

::: {.notes}
**particularly the assumption of equal dispersions and zero correlation**
:::

---

### So, are Case V assumptions violated?

::: incremental
1. Equal dispersion **may not be applicable** when researchers assess complex traits or heterogeneous stimuli 

::: incremental 
::: {style="font-size:80%;"}
- Evidence of this can be found in misfit statistics?
:::

:::

2. Zero correlation is **almost certainly invalid** in two scenarios: 

::: incremental
::: {style="font-size:80%;"}
- when comparison involves multidimensional, complex traits with heterogeneous stimuli
- when an additional hierarchical structure is relevant to the stimuli.
:::

:::

:::

::: {.notes}
**Equal dispersion:**

- "misfits" texts are texts with more judgment discrepancies than others [@Pollitt_2012a; @Pollitt_2012b; @vanDaal_et_al_2016; @Goossens_et_al_2018]
- "misfit" judges are judges who deviate substantially from the shared consensus.

**Zero correlation:**

- additional relevant characteristics, exert an uneven influence on judges' perceptions, creating biases. Since the discriminal difference of the stimuli becomes an observable outcome only through the judges' perceptions, these biases introduce dependencies between the stimuli.
- the shared context created by additional hierarchical structures introduce dependencies between stimuli (clustering) **Not properly handled**
:::

---

### So, what are the problems then?

::: incremental
a. Different dispersions, neglecting judges' biases and hierarchical structures
    
    $\longrightarrow$ reduce precision of parameter estimates
    
    $\longrightarrow$ overestimation of trait's reliability 

    $\longrightarrow$ drawing spurious conclusions [@McElreath_2020, pp. 370]

b. Discarding 'misfit' observations [@Pollitt_2012a; @Pollitt_2012b; @vanDaal_et_al_2016; @Goossens_et_al_2018] 

    $\longrightarrow$ discard valuable information 
    
    $\longrightarrow$ introduce bias into trait estimates [@Zimmerman_1994; @McElreath_2020, chap. 12]
    
    $\longrightarrow$ drawing spurious conclusions [@McElreath_2020, pp. 370]
    
:::

::: {.notes}
- discarding 'misfit' observations is a conventional practice in CJ
:::

---

## 3.2 Measurement and hypothesis tests

Researchers use the BTL model as a **measurement model** for CJ [@Laming_2004; @Pollitt_2012b; @Whitehouse_2012; @vanDaal_et_al_2016; @Lesterhuis_2018_thesis; @Coertjens_et_al_2017; @Goossens_et_al_2018; @Bouwer_et_al_2023], i.e., they use the **estimated BTL scores**, or their transformations, to conduct additional analyses or hypothesis tests, for example:


::: incremental
::: {style="font-size:80%;"}
- Identify 'misfit' judges and stimuli [@Pollitt_2012b; @vanDaal_et_al_2016; @Goossens_et_al_2018] 
- Detect biases in judges' ratings [@Pollitt_et_al_2003; @Pollitt_2012b] 
- Calculate correlations with other assessment methods [@Goossens_et_al_2018; @Bouwer_et_al_2023], 
- Test hypotheses related to the underlying trait of interest [@Casalicchio_et_al_2015; @Bramley_et_al_2019; @Boonen_et_al_2020; @Bouwer_et_al_2023; @vanDaal_et_al_2017; @Jones_et_al_2019; @Gijsen_et_al_2021]
:::

:::


---

### So, what are the problems then?

::: incremental
a. Ignoring uncertainty of BTL scores
    
    $\longrightarrow$ bias + reduce the precision of hypothesis tests [@Kline_et_al_2023, pp. 25; @Hoyle_et_al_2023, pp. 137]
    
    $\longrightarrow$ diminishing their statistical power 
    
    $\longrightarrow$ increasing likelihood of type-I or type-II errors [@McElreath_2020]
    
:::

::: {.notes}
- We need a more systematic and integrated framework that enhances statistical accuracy while strengthening measurement reliability and validity.
:::






# 4. Extending Thurstone's theory

---

## 4. Extending Thurstone's theory

::: {.fragment}
We use the **_structural approach_** to causal inference [@Pearl_2009; @Pearl_et_al_2016; @Gross_et_al_2018; @Neal_2020] to formally and graphically representing the assumed (causal) structure of the CJ system. Specifically we use:

::: incremental
a. Structural Causal Models (SCMs) and 
b. Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- Essentially, SCMs and DAGs function as *conceptual models* on which identification analysis rests [@Schuessler_et_al_2023, pp. 4]. 
- *Identification analysis* helps researchers to determine whether an estimator can accurately compute an estimand based solely on its (causal) assumptions, regardless of random variability [@Schuessler_et_al_2023, pp. 4].
- Identification is crucial because it is a necessary condition for ensuring consistent estimators. 
- *Consistency* refers to the property of an estimator whose estimates converge to the "true" value of the estimand as the data size approaches infinity [@Everitt_et_al_2010]. 
- Without identification, consistency cannot be achieved, even with "infinite" and error-free data. Thus, deriving meaningful insights from finite data becomes impossible [@Schuessler_et_al_2023, pp. 5].
:::

---

## 4. Extending Thurstone's theory

::: {.fragment}
**Motivating example:** "To what extent do different teaching methods influence students' ability to produce high-quality written texts?" 
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Solution:** Researchers design a CJ experiment.
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Assume:**

::: incremental
::: {style="font-size:80%;"}
a. researcher randomly assign students to two groups, each receiving a different teaching method. 
b. judges then compare pairs of students’ written texts
c. judges produce a dichotomous outcome, reflecting the relative quality of each text
:::
:::

:::

## 4.1 The conceptual-population model

::: {.fragment}
Assuming we have access to comparison data from a conceptual population, that is, data representing:
:::

::: incremental
::: {style="font-size:80%;"}
a. all repeated judgments 
b. made by every available judge
c. for each pair of stimuli
d. produced by each pair of individuals
:::
:::

---

## 4.1 The conceptual-population model

::: incremental
::: {style="font-size:60%;"}
- $n_{I}$ represents the number of individuals 
- $n_{A}$ denotes the number of stimuli available per individual
- $n_{J}$ indicates the total number of judges, and 
- $n_{K}$ represents the number of judgments each judge performs
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {style="font-size:45%;"}

$$
I_{n_{I}} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
2 \\
\vdots \\
h \\
\vdots \\
i \\
\vdots \\
n_{I}
\end{bmatrix} ; \;
IA_{(n_{I} \cdot n_{A}) \times 2} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 \\
1 & 2 \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
1 & n_{A}-1 \\
1 & n_{A} \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
h & a \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
i & b \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
n_{I} & n_{A}-1 \\
n_{I} & n_{A} \\
\end{bmatrix} ; \;
J_{n_{J}} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
2 \\
\vdots \\
j \\
\vdots \\
n_{J}
\end{bmatrix} ; \;
JK_{(n_{J} \cdot n_{K}) \times 2} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 \\
1 & 2 \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
1 & n_{K}-1 \\
1 & n_{K} \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
j & k \\
\vdots & \vdots \\
n_{J} & n_{K}-1 \\
n_{J} & n_{K} \\
\end{bmatrix}
$$ {#eq-mat12}

:::
:::


## 4.1 The conceptual-population model


::: incremental
::: {style="font-size:60%;"}
- ${n_{I} \cdot n_{A} \choose 2} = \frac{ (n_{I} \cdot n_{A})! }{ 2! (n_{I} \cdot n_{A} - 2)! }$
- $n = {n_{I} \cdot n_{A} \choose 2} \cdot n_{J} \cdot n_{K}$ 
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {style="font-size:45%;"}

$$
RPUV_{n \times 6} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 & 1 & 2 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 1 & 1 & 2 & 1 & 2 \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots\\
1 & 1 & 1 & 2 & 1 & n_{K}-1 \\
1 & 1 & 1 & 2 & 1 & n_{K} \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots\\
h & i & a & b & j & k \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots\\
n_{I} & n_{I} & n_{A}-1 & n_{A} & n_{J} & 1 \\
n_{I} & n_{I} & n_{A}-1 & n_{A} & n_{J} & 2 \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots\\
n_{I} & n_{I} & n_{A}-1 & n_{A} & n_{J} & n_{K}-1 \\
n_{I} & n_{I} & n_{A}-1 & n_{A} & n_{J} & n_{K} \\
\end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{N}
$$ {#eq-mat3}

:::
:::

# 5. Abandoning the BTL model

---

## 5. Abandoning the BTL model
::: {.fragment}

::: {#fig-cj15 layout-ncol=2}

::: {#fig-cj15_stat style="font-size:40%;"}
$$
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & = O^{sc}_{RPUV} \odot C \\
  O^{sc}_{RPUV} & = O^{cp}_{RPUV} \odot S_{RPUV} \\
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & \sim \text{Bernoulli} \left[ \text{inv_logit}( D_{RPUV} ) \right] \\
  D_{RPUV} & = \left( T_{IA}[R_{1},P_{1}] - T_{IA}[R_{2},P_{2}] \right) + B_{JK}[U,V] \\
  T_{IA} & = T_{I} + \beta_{XA} X_{IA} + e_{IA} \\
  T_{I} & = \beta_{XI} X_{I} + e_{I} \\
  B_{JK} & = B_{J} + \beta_{ZK} Z_{JK} + e_{JK} \\
  B_{J} & = \beta_{ZJ} Z_{J} + e_{J} \\
  e_{IA} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{IA}) \\  
  e_{I} & \sim \text{Normal}(0,1) \\
  e_{JK} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{JK}) \\
  e_{J} & \sim \text{Normal}(0,1)
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {#fig-cj15_scm style="font-size:40%;"}
$$
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & := f_{C}(O^{sc}_{RPUV}, C) \\
  O^{sc}_{RPUV} & := f_{O}(O^{cp}_{RPUV}, S_{R}, S_{P}, S_{U}, S_{V}) \\
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & := f_{O}(D_{RPUV}) \\
  D_{RPUV} & := f_{D}(T_{IA}, B_{JK}) \\
  T_{IA} & := f_{T}(T_{I}, X_{A}, e_{IA}) \\
  T_{I} & := f_{T}(X_{I}, e_{I}) \\
  B_{JK} & := f_{B}(B_{J}, Z_{K}, e_{JK}) \\
  B_{J} & := f_{B}(Z_{J}, e_{J}) \\
  e_{IA} & \dsep \{ e_{I}, e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{I} & \dsep \{ e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{JK} & \dsep e_{J}
\end{aligned}
$$
:::
:::

Sample-comparison model including sample and comparison mechanisms. Panel (a) illustrates the SCM. Panel (b) depicts the associated DAG.
:::
